get.description:
Chat notifies updated events on these endpoints, typically in this order:

* `/chat/v1/session`    ->  { state: "connecting", pid: "", name: "", loaded: false }    //chat is now connecting (empty pid, name)
* `/chat/v1/session`    ->  { state: "connected", pid: "sum3530124@pvp.net", name: "Scarlet Witch", loaded: false }    //chat is now connected initial data for showing the friends list in the UX is not loaded
* `/chat/v#/presences`      //for all your friend presences (no way around this currently)
* `/chat/v#/presences`      //for yourself
* `/chat/v#/groups`         //batch of every group in your friends list
* `/chat/v#/friends`        //batch
* `/chat/v#/blocked`        //batch
* `/chat/v#/conversations`  //recent conversations
* `/chat/v#/messages`
* `/chat/v#/participants`
* `/chat/v1/session`     -> { state: "connected", pid: "sum3530124@pvp.net", name: "Scarlet Witch", loaded: true }    //chat is now connected and has loaded the initial data to show in the UX

get.description:
**Response:**

```
{
  "bounceDockIconEnabled": [bounceDockIconEnabled], // If the dock icon will bounce when receiving a new message, game invite, etc
  "chat-status-message": "[status_message]",      // The player's status message. This gets updated within chat when the "status" of the player is changed
  "chatFilterDisabled": [chatFilterDisabled],       // If bad language is filtered in chat messages
  "chatGroupMobile": [chatGroupMobile],             // If mobile friends are grouped in their own "MOBILE" folder
  "chatGroupOffline": [chatGroupOffline],           // If offline friends are grouped in their own "OFFLINE" folder
  "chatWindow": {                                   // The chat window settings
    "detached": [detached],                         // If the chat window is docked or popped out
    "height": [height],                             // The height of the chat window
    "left": [left],                                 // The location of the left side of the chat window
    "top": [top],                                   // The location of the top side of the chat window
    "width": [width]                                // The width of the chat window
  },
  "closed-conversations": {                         // Which conversations have been closed. Used within chat to determine which recent convos to remove on startup. This gets updated
                                                      // within chat when a conversation is deleted
    "[convo_id]": [closed_timestamp],
    ...
  },
  "friendRequestToastsDisabled": [friendRequestToastsDisabled], // If a toast appears when you receive a friend request
  "linkClickWarningEnabled": [linkClickWarningEnabled],         // If a link warning will appear when clicking on links
  "messageNotificationsEnabled": [messageNotificationsEnabled], // If a native toast or regular toast appears when receiving a message
  "moreUnreadsEnabled": [moreUnreadsEnabled],                   // If a "more unreads" indicator appears for unread items not currently in scroll view
  "muted-conversations": {                                      // A list of 1:1 muted conversations. This gets updated within chat when the "muted" state of a conversation is changed
    "[convo_id]": 1
  },                       
  "recentlyPlayedOpen": [recentlyPlayedOpen],                  // If the "recently played" folder is open
  "roster-group-collapsed": {                                  // A list of each folder's collapsed state. This gets updated within chat when the "collapsed" state of a group is changed
    "[group_folder_name]": [collapsed],
    ...
  },
  "showWhenTypingEnabled": [showWhenTypingEnabled],            // If an indicator is shown to other players when writing a message to them
  "sortBy": "[sort_type]"                                    // How to sort friends in the friends list (ex. by "availability" vs "alphabetical")
}
```

Most of these chat settings are straightforward and only require an update when a player enables or disables a setting. For example, when they check or uncheck a box for the setting.

get.description:
**Response:** list of error objects (could have zero or more entries):

```
{ "errors": [
              { "class":   "[class]",        //source of error (muc, presence, friend, etc)
                "subtype": "[subtype]",      //extra detail; usually most descriptive - along with text field
                "type":    "[type]",         //detail - usually action based on error??? (cancel, ignore, etc)
                "code":    "[code]",         //numeric error code
                "text":    "[description]",  //if available; usually most descriptive (when provided) - along with subtype field
                "[key]":   "[value]",        //extra available data, such as...
                "pid":     "[{pid}]",        //player id if available
                "cid":     "[{cid}]",        //conversation id if available
                "id":      "[error id]",     //unique among all errors
                "ts":      "[timestamp]"     //integer value: milliseconds UTC
              },
              { "class":   "muc",           //EXAMPLE ERROR OF FAILURE TO JOIN MUC
                "subtype": "not-allowed",
                "type":    "cancel",
                "text":    "",
                "code":    "405",
                "pid":     "sum3530124@pvp.net",
                "cid":     "2785eb60-495f-4037-9fa0-98d70bac1b00@pgc.pvp.net",
                "id":      "e_1491935420384"
                "ts":      "1491935419627"
              },
              { "class":   "auth",          //EXAMPLE ERROR OF FAILURE TO LOGIN TO CHAT
                "id":      "e_auth",
                "code":    "401",
                "type":    "temporary-auth-failure"
                "ts":      "1497989043000",
                "cid":     "",
                "pid":     "",
                "subtype": "",
                "text":    "",
              },
              ...
            ]
}
```

**Notes:**

* Errors for group chat (multi-user chat: MUC) will have "class":"muc" and a "cuuid" field
* Usually the "subtype" and the "text" fields are most descriptive, if they exist

get.description:
**Response**: named messages root object: a flat list of message property groups (could have zero or more entries):

```
{ "messages": [
                  { "body": "[message]",            //actual text of this message
                    "pid":  "[{pid}]",              //pid of sender
                    "name": "[name]",               //name of sender
                    "ts":   "[timestamp]",          //integer value: milliseconds UTC
                    "cid":  "[cid]",                //conversation id
                    "id":   "[message id]",         //unique key within the conversation - for storage
                    "read": true/false,               //whether message has been marked as read or not
                    "type": "[chat, groupchat, dm]" //how the message was sent: from friend, from group chat, or a direct message from player in a group chat
                  },
                  { "body": "[message]",
                    "pid":  "[{pid}]",
                    "ts":   "[timestamp]",
                    "cid":  "[cid]",
                    "id":   "[message id]",
                    "read": true/false,
                    "type": "[chat, groupchat, dm]"
                  },
                  ...
                ]
}
```

**NOTE**: messages are sorted by time-stamp, earliest first, latest last


Endpoint deleted August 2021; Please use 'chat/v6/messages'.

parameters.description: Conversation ID. Omit to retrieve all messages of all conversations.
parameters.name: cid

parameters.description: Message ID, unique within the conversation, only used if cid query arg provided
parameters.name: mid

get.summary: Get conversation messages

post.description:
**Sending A Message**
A conversation id (cid) can be a MUC cid or for peer to peer messages, a player id (pid) can be used as a cid.

```
POST /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages      //cid is the conversation id passed as a path argument
```
Data:

```
{
  "message": "[message]" //the text to send
  "type"   : "[chat, groupchat, dm]"
}
```
Additional notes:

* type - used to specify the type of message (inferred from conversation type if left blank)
  * chat: for P2P messages with friends
  * groupchat: for group messages within a group chat
  * dm: for Direct Messages with somebody in a group chat with you, or with a friend

As players post messages to a conversation, chat notifies on REST in this order:

* /chat/v3/conversations/
  * with updated data:  "unread_count" and the last message ID in the conversation
* /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages
  * a list of new messages for the conversation (earliest first, latest last, but many times just one new message)

**Direct Messages (private messages within a group chat)**

Private messages between players that are not friends are possible, and this messaging is always tied to a JWT authenticated group chat (MUC) that both players are a part of. The MUC they are a part of has its own conversation-id (cid) and the private conversation between participants includes that cid in its derived cid.  For example if players "Brad" and "Sue" are both in MUC "lobby01@league.pvp.net" and Brad sends a direct message to Sue, then his client will...

```
POST /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages      //where cid = "lobby01@league.pvp.net/Sue"
```
NOTE: all {cid} values should be URL encoded, so the example cid when sent url encoded is "lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FSue"

Data:

```
{
  "message": "[message]" //the text to send
  "type"   : "dm"
}      
```
Additional notes:

* The conversation object (and child objects like messages) from Brad's perspective will be at: /chat/v3/conversations/lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FSue
* The conversation from Sue's perspective will be at:  /chat/v3/conversations/lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FBrad
* All operations (GET participants, GET messages, POST messages, etc) are the same as regular conversations
* for direct messaging, the conversation "type" and the message "type" will always be "dm"

get.description:
**Response**: named messages root object: a flat list of message property groups (could have zero or more entries):

```
{ "messages": [
                  { "body": "[message]",            //actual text of this message
                    "pid":  "[{pid}]",              //pid of sender
                    "name": "[name]",               //name of sender
                    "ts":   "[timestamp]",          //integer value: milliseconds UTC
                    "cid":  "[cid]",                //conversation id
                    "id":   "[message id]",         //unique key within the conversation - for storage
                    "read": true/false,               //whether message has been marked as read or not
                    "type": "[chat, groupchat, dm]" //how the message was sent: from friend, from group chat, or a direct message from player in a group chat
                  },
                  { "body": "[message]",
                    "pid":  "[{pid}]",
                    "ts":   "[timestamp]",
                    "cid":  "[cid]",
                    "id":   "[message id]",
                    "read": true/false,
                    "type": "[chat, groupchat, dm]"
                  },
                  ...
                ]
}
```

**NOTE**: messages are sorted by time-stamp, earliest first, latest last

parameters.description: Conversation ID. Omit to retrieve all messages of all conversations.

get.summary: Get conversation messages

post.description:
**Sending A Message**
A conversation id (cid) can be a MUC cid or for peer to peer messages, a player id (pid) can be used as a cid.

```
POST /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages      //cid is the conversation id passed as a path argument
```
Data:

```
{
  "message": "[message]" //the text to send
  "type"   : "[chat, groupchat, dm]"
}
```
Additional notes:

* type - used to specify the type of message (inferred from conversation type if left blank)
  * chat: for P2P messages with friends
  * groupchat: for group messages within a group chat
  * dm: for Direct Messages with somebody in a group chat with you, or with a friend

As players post messages to a conversation, chat notifies on REST in this order:

* /chat/v3/conversations/
  * with updated data:  "unread_count" and the last message ID in the conversation
* /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages
  * a list of new messages for the conversation (earliest first, latest last, but many times just one new message)

**Direct Messages (private messages within a group chat)**

Private messages between players that are not friends are possible, and this messaging is always tied to a JWT authenticated group chat (MUC) that both players are a part of. The MUC they are a part of has its own conversation-id (cid) and the private conversation between participants includes that cid in its derived cid.  For example if players "Brad" and "Sue" are both in MUC "lobby01@league.pvp.net" and Brad sends a direct message to Sue, then his client will...

```
POST /chat/v3/conversations/{cid}/messages      //where cid = "lobby01@league.pvp.net/Sue"
```
NOTE: all {cid} values should be URL encoded, so the example cid when sent url encoded is "lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FSue"

Data:

```
{
  "message": "[message]" //the text to send
  "type"   : "dm"
}      
```
Additional notes:

* The conversation object (and child objects like messages) from Brad's perspective will be at: /chat/v3/conversations/lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FSue
* The conversation from Sue's perspective will be at:  /chat/v3/conversations/lobby01%40league.pvp.net%2FBrad
* All operations (GET participants, GET messages, POST messages, etc) are the same as regular conversations
* for direct messaging, the conversation "type" and the message "type" will always be "dm"

get.description:
Returns an individual configuration field for the requesting application. Both Public and Player types are checked. Subscribing to a configuration field that does not exist results in event UPDATE notifications with an `BindingProperty::Empty` data field. If the receiving module intends to handle the does-not-exist case, the event handler should accept a BindingProperty, not a concrete resource type. 

* This call does not block. If config is not already cached locally, an async request will be dispatched.

* If configuration has not yet been fetched, an HTTP 202 is returned. When the configuration is available, a resource notification will be sent to subscribers.

* Configuration is automatically refreshed on state change (login, logout, or notification of change), and apps may be notified by subscribing to this endpoint.

* Connecting game applications will have product information automatically applied to outgoing configuration requests (i.e. app name, version, patchline). This allows configuration overrides to be applied specifically for the app.

Response codes:
- 200 If the field exists. The body will be the configuration value.
- 202 If configuration has not yet been fetched, and updates can be received via subscription notifications.
- 204 If the field does not exist, and all configuration has been successfully fetched.

parameters.description: Name of the config to fetch the value of (i.e. aurelian.game_server.url)
parameters.name: name

Returns an object containing metadata about the most recent published EULA, and a field, 'acceptance', indicating whether the user has accepted this agreement or not. (The 'acceptance' field is accessible separately via the /acceptance endpoint.

When the 'acceptance' field is 'WaitingForAllServiceData', we don't have the data for the latest EULA, nor its acceptance state, and all other fields are invalid.

Returns the acceptance state of the most recent EULA for the current user. Possible values are:

- WaitingForAllServiceData: The user is signed out, we have yet to retrieve client-config, or we are otherwise waiting for data to determine if the user has accepted the latest agreement.
- AcceptanceRequired: The user has never accepted a EULA, or has not accepted the most recent version.
- Accepted: The user has accepted the most recent EULA.

**Description**

This API will check if the user has made any purchases on the first party store and will attempt to fulfill them.
This should typically be called when the game is launched or resumed.

** Request Arguments **

Request Body:
* `firstPartyAuthToken`: Authentication token for the first party platform required to perform fulfillment.
    * On Nintendo Switch, provide the NSA ID token if available. Otherwise, RiotGamesApi will fetch the NSA ID token itself.
    * On Playstation 4 and Playstation 5, provide an NP auth code that includes the "psn:s2s" and "openid" scopes.
    * On Xbox, no token is required and an empty string can be provided.
* `fulfillmentId`: UUID that identifies a unique fulfillment attempt.
* `fulfillmentReason`: The reason why the fulfillment attempt was made. Possible options are listed below:
    * `GameLaunched`: Fulfillment was initiated because a purchase may have occurred while the game was not running.
    * `GameReturnedToForeground`: Fulfillment was initiated because a purchase may have occurred while the game was in the background.
    * `PurchaseCompleted`: Fulfillment was initiated because a purchase was completed (likely from the in-game store).
    * `Other`: DO NOT USE without consulting the SDK Features team first. This is a fallback reason for why a fulfillment was initiated if it
      is not covered by any of the existing reasons. However, you should only use this if SDK Features is not able to add a reason that covers
      your use case before you need to use it and once SDK Features does add the reason, you are expected to update to using it as soon as it
      has been made available in the next SDK release.

** Returns **

Response Body:
* `FulfillmentResponse` Object:
    * `fulfillmentRequired`: Bool indicating whether the player owned anything that needed to be fulfilled.
    * `fulfilledItems`: An `ItemFulfillmentSuccessInfo` object
        * `itemId`: A string that identifies the item that was fulfilled.
        * `quantity`: An integer representing how many of the item was fulfilled.
    * `unfulfilledItems`: An `ItemFulfillmentFailureInfo` object
        * `itemId`: A string that identifies the item that was unable to be fulfilled.
        * `quantity`: An integer representing how many of the item could not be fulfilled.
        * `reason`: A string describing why the item could not be fulfilled.

** Error Codes **
* Possible error codes: 400, 403, 412, 417, 500, 502, 504, 512
* Error codes fall into the following categories: recoverable, retriable, and hard failure.
* Recoverable errors (400, 403, 412) will succeed when the root issue is resolved such as "412 Unable to perform fulfillment because plugin is not enabled." - in this case the plugin needs to be enabled in the config
* Retriable errors (500, 502, 503, 504) may succeed if another attempt is made later. This could include issues such as the network temporarily being down.
* Hard failure (417, 512) errors are unlikely to succeed when retried and the root issue is unexpected. An example of this would be the first party libraries failing to load.
* For more details on error codes and how to handle them please see https://platform.riotgames.com/riotgamesapi-sdk/features/first-party-fulfillment/integrating-first-party-fulfillment

put.description:
**Description**

Sets whether or not the plugin should use a mock fulfillment API or not, and if it should, how the mock API should behave.

**Argument**

* `state`: String value determining if the mock fulfillment API should be used, and if so, how it will behave. Possible values are listed below:
    * `NoMock`: The plugin will not use the mock API and will toggle back to using the fulfillment API it was initialized with.
    * `NoFulfillmentRequired`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return that no fulfillment is required.
    * `FirstPartyQueryConsumableFailed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an error when attempting to query if there are
      consumable items to fulfill.
    * `FirstPartyQueryNonConsumableFailed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an error when attempting to query if there are
      non-consumable items to fulfill.
    * `FirstPartyAuthorizationFailed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an error when attempting to fetch the
      first party authorization.
    * `FirstPartyQueryByRiotPayFailed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an error indicating RiotPay could not
      call the first party services to verify the fulfillment request.
    * `RiotPayFulfillmentFailed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an error indicating RiotPay failed to complete
      the fulfillment request entirely.
    * `PartialFulfillmentCompleted`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a response indicating that RiotPay managed
      to fulfill some items, but failed to fulfill others.
    * `SuccessConsumable`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return as if all consumable items have been fulfilled successfully.
    * `SuccessNonConsumable`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return as if all non-consumable items have been fulfilled successfully.

parameters.description: A string determining how the mock fulfillment API should behave. See help text for possible values.
parameters.name: state

get.description:
**Description**

You will only get warnings for the current game. To make testing easier, there are debug endpoints on this plugin that allow you to mock your current game.

**Response Body**

* `gaWarningMessage`: Top-level response field. If there are no unacknowledged warnings, this will be empty object `{}`.
Otherwise it will contain unacknowledged warnings keyed by their ID.
* `gaWarningMessage.{id}`: Represents a single unacknowledged warning.
  * `gaWarningMessage.{id}.category`: Category of the warning message--internal string.
  * `gaWarningMessage.{id}.locale`: Detected locale of player and what locale the message was localized to.
  * `gaWarningMessage.{id}.message`: Localized message to display to player.
  * `gaWarningMessage.{id}.title`: Localized message title to display to player.
  * `gaWarningMessage.{id}.acknowledgeText`: Localized text player must type to acknowledge the warning.
  * (OPTIONAL) `gaWarningMessage.{id}.seeMoreUrl`: Hyperlink to give players more context about community guidelines. This field and `seeMoreLabel` won't always be present and you should build your UI to account for that.
  * (OPTIONAL) `gaWarningMessage.{id}.seeMoreLabel`: Label for `seeMoreUrl`. Do not display the raw link, use this label instead. This field and `seeMoreUrl` won't always be present and you should build your UI to account for that.

**Response Codes**
* `200`: Success.
* `401`: Player must be logged in.

**Notes**
* Allows you to perform a repair on a set of files or a full repair without having to wait or game client to exit. Only use this if you're
absolutely certain that the files are not currently in use.
* Game is responsible for displaying repair progress and can get progress using the GET /patch/v1/installs/{install-id}/status/repair endpoint.

**Data**
* `files`: a list of file paths for files that need to be repaired. If none specified then the patcher will perform a full repair. File paths must
be relative to the install root.
* `manifest_url`: Url for the release manifest.
* `headers`: Headers to send with every request. If the manifest url is behind SCD then a Cookie header is required.
* `max_download_speed`: Maximum download speed, in bytes/sec. If zero then no limits will be applied.
* `allowed_http_fallback_hostnames`: List of hostnames for which we'll fall back to HTTP instead of HTTPS if they resolve to an RFC1918 private IP address.
* `delete_foreign_paths`:  (optional) If true, paths that are not considered part of the install will be checked during the verification and repair processes and removed.

get.description:
**Note**
* The status is always relative to a manifest and set of tags, specified by the `url` and `tags` fields respectively.
* If there is any work in progress, `url` and `tags` will match those from the request.
* If there are no pending requests, `url` and `tags` will match the files in the install folder.

**Responses**

**Patch**
* `updating`: Currently performing a patching / seeding request.
* `out_of_date`: The last request was partially completed and more work needs to be done before all files are in sync with the release manifest.
* `up_to_date`: The last request completed successfully and files are in sync with the release manifest.
* `not_installed`: The last request completed successfully and detected that the install-id is not installed.
* `pending_verify`: The last request has not completed verification step.

**Seed**
* `seeding`: Currently performing a seeding request.
* `out_of_date`: The last request was partially completed and more work needs to be done before all data needed to update the install has been downloaded.
* `up_to_date`: The last request completed successfully and all data needed to update the install has been downloaded.
* `pending_verify`: The last request has not completed verification step.

**Preview**
* `pending`: The preview request has not finished.
* `done`: The last preview request completed successfully.

**Repair**
* `manifest_url`: the url of the release manifest.
* `repair_progress`: The progress of the repair operation. Contains:
    * `bytes_to_repair`: Total number of bytes to read.
    * `files_to_repair`: Total number of files to read.
    * `repaired_bytes`: Number of bytes read from disk so far.
    * `repaired_files`: Number of files read from disk so far.
* `state`: The overall state of the repair operation. Possible states include:
    * `pending`: No repair requests have been made.
    * `in_progress`: Repair is in progress.
    * `canceled`: The repair operation was canceled.
    * `done`: Repair operation is complete.

parameters.name: install-id

get.description:
**Notes**
* The status is always relative to a manifest and set of tags, specified by the `url` and `tags` fields respectively.
* If there is any work in progress, `url` and `tags` will match those from the request.
* If there are no pending requests, `url` and `tags` will match the files in the install folder.

**Response**

The `state` field will is populated based on the current work with the following values:
* `updating`: Currently performing a patching / seeding request.
* `out_of_date`: The last request was partially completed and more work needs to be done before all files are in sync with the release manifest.
* `up_to_date`: The last request completed successfully and files are in sync with the release manifest.
* `not_installed`: The last request completed successfully and detected that the install-id is not installed.
* `pending_verify`: The last request has not completed verification step.

parameters.description: The id of the install
parameters.name: install-id

get.description:
**Response**
* `manifest_url`: the url of the release manifest.
* `repair_progress`: The progress of the repair operation. Contains:
    * `bytes_to_repair`: Total number of bytes to read.
    * `files_to_repair`: Total number of files to read.
    * `repaired_bytes`: Number of bytes read from disk so far.
    * `repaired_files`: Number of files read from disk so far.
* `state`: The overall state of the repair operation.
    * `pending`: No repair requests have been made.
    * `in_progress`: Repair is in progress.
    * `canceled`: The repair operation was canceled.
    * `done`: Repair operation is complete.

put.description:
**Description**

Sets whether or not the plugin should use a mock platform social API or not, and if it should, how the mock API should behave.

**Argument**

* `state`: String value determining if the mock fulfillment API should be used, and if so, how it will behave. Possible values are listed below:
    * `NoMock`: The plugin will not use the mock API and will toggle back to using the fulfillment API it was initialized with.
    * `FriendListEmpty`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an empty friend list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `BlockListEmpty`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return an empty block list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `BlockListNotifyUpdate`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will send a notification with a non-empty block list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `BlockListNotifyDelete`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will send a notification with an empty block list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `FriendListNotifyUpdate`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will send a notification with a non-empty friend list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `FriendListNotifyDelete`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will send a notification with an empty friend list and allow voice chat to be used.
    * `TextPermissionNotAllowed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a populated block list and not allow text chat to be used.
    * `VoicePermissionNotAllowed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a populated block list and not allow voice chat to be used.
    * `CrossPlayPermissionNotAllowed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a populated block list and not allow cross play to be used.
    * `MultiplayerPermissionNotAllowed`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a populated block list and not allow multiplayer features to be used.
    * `Success`: The plugin is set to use the mock API. The mock API will return a populated block list and allow voice chat to be used.

parameters.description: A string determining how the mock platform social API should behave. See help text for possible values.
parameters.name: state

**Description**
Retrieves the namesets for the PUUID provided.
A Nameset contains the player's name on the given platform.
Example: SwitchNameset.name would be the Switch username associated with the player's PUUID

** Body Argument **

"NamesetsForPuuidRequest"
* "puuid" - PUUID (String)

Response Body:
NamesetsForPuuidResponse:
* "puuid" - PUUID (String)
* "providerId" - player's provider id
* "switchNameset" - A SwitchNameset
* "playstationNameset" - A PlaystationNameset
* "xboxNameset" - An XboxNameset
* "gnt" - A Riot ID
* "error" - A String containing any errors

PlaystationNameset:

XboxNameset:

post.summary: Simulate sending a Reporter Feedback message to this player with a specific report category.

post.description:
**Data**
* `categories`: List of category strings that player is reporting another player for. Different products use different categories.
* `comment`: Comment associated with this report.
* `location`: The location where the offending behavior occurred. Example: `in-game`.
* `match_token`: The reporting player's match token, which is a signed JWT. See Platform docs for more info on match tokens.
* `offender_puuid`: Whom the player is reporting.

**Response**

This endpoint can return the following response codes:
* `204`: Report successfully submitted. Note that in some cases it's intended UX that the submission is a "success" even if the report cannot be submitted.
* `401`: Client is unable to retrieve current player's access token, which is required. Most common when trying to submit a report without having first logged in.


Endpoint deleted June 2022; Please use '/player-reporting/v2/report'.

get.description:
**Data**
* Response is a JSON map of `id` --> individual reporter feedback messages. Example:
```json
{
"1": {
"locale": "en_US",
"product": "league_of_legends",
"category": "CHEATING",
"recipientType": "",
"message": "Your report of cheating has been verified.",
"title": "Report Feedback"
}
}
```

* `locale`: Detected locale of player and what locale the message was localized to.
* 'product': The product that this game is intended for. Can be a specific product, such as "league_of_legends", or it can be "riot", denoting that it's for all/any product to view.
* `category`: Category of the report--an internal string. Category keys to different localized messages.
* 'recipientType': Category of the recipient's role in the report--an internal string. recipientType keys to different localized messages. Examples are "BYSTANDER" or "". Empty string denotes the recipient was the Reporter, for backwards compatibility with old messages.
* `message`: Localized message to display to player.
* `title`: Localized message title to display to player.

Response will be an empty map `{}` if there are no reporter-feedback messages to display.

post.description:
Used to submit a player report when no signed token is available
**Data**
* `offenderId`: The id of the offender. For players this is their puuid.
* `categories`: List of category strings that player is reporting another player for. Different products use different categories.
* `location`: The location where the offending behavior occurred. Example: `in-game`.
* `comment`: Player written comment associated with this report.
* `conversationContext`: (OPTIONAL) The ID and type of conversation from where the report was filed
* `unstructuredContext`: (OPTIONAL) An additional payload where game teams can pass in custom payload to CPD for analysis

Reporting V2 is similar to v1, but the token can accept more types than just a MATCH_TOKEN to allow support for reporting guilds and potentially other entities in the future.
**Data**
* `categories`: List of category strings that player is reporting another player for. Different products use different categories.
* `comment`: Player written comment associated with this report.
* `location`: The location where the offending behavior occurred. Example: `in-game`.
* `tokenType`: The type of information the token contains. Example: `MATCH_TOKEN`, `GUILD_TOKEN`.
* `token`: A signed JWT with a format matching the tokenType. See Platform docs for more info on token formats and types.
* `offenderId`: The id of the offender. For players this is their puuid.

**Response**

This endpoint can return the following response codes:
* `204`: Report successfully submitted. Note that in some cases it's intended UX that the submission is a "success" even if the report cannot be submitted.
* `401`: Client is unable to retrieve current player's access token, which is required. Most common when trying to submit a report without having first logged in.

get.description:
**iOS specific considerations**

When the setting is changed while the game is in the background, the RiotGamesApi currently does not
immediately get notified of a change in tracking permissions, but checks again as those permissions
are required, and notifies on change. If games need real-time access to tracking settings after a
background, calling this endpoint after a return from background will force the SDK to look for
setting changes immediately and will also trigger a notification if the value has changed.

**Response Codes**
- `200`: Privacy settings and state are available.

**Data**
- `canUseTracking`: If `true`, the player's tracking information can be used.
- `canRequestTrackingPermission`: If `true`, POST /privacy/v1/tracking/request-permission to request
  permission to track the player.
- `state`: Indicates if we have not yet requested tracking permissions (`Unrequested`), if we are
  in the process of requesting permission to track (`Requesting`), and if we have completed that
  request at any time in the past (`Completed`).
get.summary: Retrieves privacy tracking settings and state.

post.description:
**Response Codes**
- `200`: Request is in flight, subscribe to `/privacy/v1/tracking` for updates.
- `405`: Unable to request permission for this platform.
- `409`: A request for permission is already in flight, or is unnecessary (for instance, if the
  player has declined tracking.)
- `500`: The Info.plist file for the app is missing a NSUserTrackingUsageDescription entry. The
  Apple APIs cannot function without it.
post.summary: Ask the player for permission to track them via telemetry

put.description:
## Context
This function is being added the support the ability for standalone games to set product locale. The behavior works as follows:
- First verify that the locale attempting to be set is listed as an available product locale. No actual validation is done on the product locale itself, just that it is present
in the list of available locales stored in the configuration keyed locale_data.available_locales.
- After confirming the validity, we attempt to find the product settings file. If it exists, it means that we are in standalone SDK mode. We then propagate the locale to the file
to persist it across sessions
- If the file does not exist, it means that we are being run through the Riot Client, and instead we call the `PUT /riotclient/product-locales/products/%s/patchlines/%s`
endpoint to set the product locale for that product + patchline combination.

### Legacy support
League of Legends unofficially supports players setting their locale to values that are not available to the region. For example, setting their NA client to ja_JP. This is done
currently via modifying the LeagueClientSettings.yaml file and explicitly setting their locale to their locale of choice. We want to continue to support this behavior on behalf
of League. This function does not modify the validation or ability to override your locale. The validation done here on this function behaves the same as the existing Riot Client
validation, which continues to allow for player modifications.

If that should change in the future, this function will need to be updated to reflect the changes as well as the `PUT /riotclient/product-locales/products/%s/patchlines/%s` endpoint.

## Arguments
- locale
  - the 4 letter code representing the country + language specified separated by an underscore. For example, ja_JP is Japanese, and en_US is US English.
  - no validation on the 4 letter codes are done; we merely check for its existence in the list of available locales.

parameters.description: Locale to set product to
parameters.name: locale

put.summary: Applies the locale specified in the body to the product currently running. Locale should be in language_country format. for example, zh_CN or ko_KR

post.description:
* Call this endpoint periodically to verify that Riot Client is still responding.

* Upon your product entering the 'Gameplay' phase, Riot Client will lock patching and prevent updates to products or Riot Client in the case of a crash and restart, prioritizing launching the game promptly.

* Products should include a 'User-Agent' header per RFC-0031d. 

* If this call fails and your sessionID is valid, then you can begin the recovery process specified in RFC-1064.

* Riot Client expects this heartbeat from your application on a regular interval (once every 10-60 seconds) in order to make sure your application is not hung or otherwise unresponsive.

parameters.description: Information about the current state of the product (i.e. idle, in game, etc)
parameters.name: heartbeat-info

Periodic heartbeat made by products to update Riot Client with state of gameplay, and to verify connectivity to Riot Client. 

SessionId is derived from 'session' HTTP header, or websocket authentication.

* Products should include a 'User-Agent' header per RFC-0031d. 

* If this call fails and your sessionID is valid, then you can begin the recovery process specified in RFC-1064.

delete.description: This method destroys both the client-side authorization and revokes refresh tokens (if any) on the server. As a result, this request can fail if the authorization server is down. In the face of failure, the client still forgets the authorization, otherwise server-side downtime would prevent a player from logging out.
delete.summary: Revoke existing tokens, logging the user out.

get.description:
When the user is logged in, this resource will be populated with data about the player:

* **currentPlatformId** is the player's home platformId
* **currentAccountId** is the account ID for the player on their home platform.
* **subject** is the [RFC 0214g]()-defined globally unique identifier for the player.
* **authenticationType** is the authentication mechanism used to establish the RSO session.

While true that the player's `currentPlatformId` will usually match the `region` setting of the client, consuming plugins *must not* make this assumption. Applications *must not* create identifiers for the player by concatenating `currentAccountId` with the client's region setting. consuming plugins *should* use the `subject` to globally recognize players, but may use a concatenation of `currentPlatformId` and `currentAccountId` if subject is infeasible.

In addition, note that when a player transfers from region to region, the value of that player's `currentPlatformId` and `currentAccountId` will change, but the value of their `subject` will not.
get.summary: Retrieve a player's authorization status.

get.description:
If the player has a valid authorization, this API will return the player's access token, as well as their approximate expiration time and scope. This token can be used as the `Bearer` value of an `Authorization` header in order to make requets against services protected by RSO tokens. This token represents permission sets granted to the application by the player.

Access tokens expire. This plugin will handle refreshing access tokens automatically, but it's up to your plugin to either request an access token for each request, or subscribe to resource updated events for the token.

Access tokens are intended to be server-authoritative, despite being verifiable client-side as well. Scopes are included as a means for UIs to anticipate which scopes are available.

**Note:** This API returns the token's expiry as seconds since the unix epoch. Do not trust this value locally in the client, as the player's system clock may be incorrect. This value is *deprecated*, and may be removed in a future version.
get.summary: Retrieve a player's access token.

get.description: If the player has failed to log in via RSO, and the HTTP error code cannot uniquely disambiguate the error encountered, provides more information about the error encountered in the form of the error and errorDescription provided from RSO via OAuth errors.
get.summary: Retrieves any error received from RSO during the last authorization attempt.

post.description:
Executes OAuth2's [resource owner password credentials grant](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.3) flow in order to log the user in. If successful, it will alter trigger a modification of the `/rso-auth/v1/authorization` resource and relevant sub-resources with details of the user's session. This flow is stateless, and does not create a session with the RSO server.

In circumstances where additional data is required to log the user in (such as captcha or multi-factor authentication, this method will simply fail.

parameters.description: Username, password and platformId
parameters.name: creds

post.summary: Log the user in with username, password and platformId.

get.description:
If the player has a valid authorization, this API will return the player's id token, as well as their approximate expiration time and a JSON object of the data it includes. This token includes details about the player, signed as a means of trust. These details--called claims--are data about the player that the RSO server deems to be true at the time of authentication. There is no guarantee that these details have not changed in the interim.

Id tokens are only created at login, and cannot be refreshed, as the system's trust that the claims remain true decays over time. Expired Id tokens may continue to be used informationally, but *must not* be trusted.

**Note:** This API returns the token's expiry as seconds since the unix epoch. Do not trust this value locally in the client, as the player's system clock may be incorrect. This value is *deprecated*, and may be removed in a future version.
get.summary: Retrieve a player's ID token.

post.description:
Executes OAuth2's [refresh flow](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-6) in order to refresh an expired authorization. This API is for debugging and testing only; the RSO plugin handles refresh automatically.

Refreshes authorization for all clients that have currently active authorizations, the return value is from the main client RiotClient bootstraps with (the one from config)

get.description:
Returns a `SessionResponse` with details of the current state of the session. This is a subscribable end-point that will update as the state is updated.

When not set, the type of the `SessionResponse` will be set to `unknown_authentication_response`. The return value will also include the current state of the `persistLogin` value.
get.summary: Retrieve the current session state.

put.description:
Progresses the login flow for the session with the required player credentials.

This API should be called when prompted for `needs_authentication` from the `/rso-auth/v2/authorizations` API. Along with the user's credentials, this API will also take the `trustDevice` boolean to tell the RSO service whether or not to record this device as a trusted device to remember for use when determining trust level requirements.

This API returns a response that contains a type to determine how to follow up in the login process. If the credentials are accepted then the type will be set to `authenticated`.

If further verification is required then the type may be set to `needs_multifactor_verification`, in which case details can be found in the `MultifactorDetails`, and the required input should be PUT to `/rso-auth/v2/authentication/multifactor`

In some error cases, the `error` string may be set to indicate more information about the authentication state.

parameters.description: Player session authentication input using player credentials
parameters.name: sessionCredentials

put.summary: Update an authentication session with credentials to login.

put.description:
Authenticates a player using a token from rso-authenticator.

The `authentication_type` value should be `SSOAuth` for social/3rd party authentication tokens (e.g. Google, Facebook, etc), and `Riot Auth` for Riot Games authentication tokens.

put.description:
Progresses the login flow for the session with the required multifactor authentication.

This API should be called when prompted for `needs_multifactor_verification` after providing credentials through `/rso-auth/v2/authentication/credentials`.

The `retry` boolean can be set when calling this API to cause MFA to push the multifactor message to the user again.
In some error cases, the `error` string may be set to indicate more information about the authentication state.

parameters.description: Player session authentication input method using one time password

post.description:
Attempts to retrieve the authorization associated with the `client-id` set in the `authorizationRequest`. If the player has not been logged in, then this call will prompt that a login session be established.

When POSTing a request for authorization, the body may optionally include an array of `scope`s to be included for the authorization. Likewise, an array of `trustLevels` can be set to set the level at which the authorization state is trusted.

This API returns type: `needs_authentication` if the client requires authentication before an authorization can be presented, or type: `needs_reauthorization` if the client requires reauthentication before a new authorization can be presented, or type: `authorized` along with the `ImplicitAuthorization` field populated.

On success, this API will return type: `authorized` along with the `ImplicitAuthorization` field populated.

When PATCHing a request to update an existing authorization, the body may optionally include an array of `scope`s to be included for the authorization. Likewise, an array of `trustLevels` can be set to set the level at which the authorization state is trusted.

This API returns type: `needs_authentication` if the client requires authentication before an authorization can be presented, or type: `needs_reauthorization` if the client requires reauthentication before a new authorization can be presented, or type: `authorized` along with the `ImplicitAuthorization` field populated.

parameters.description:
A structure that contains two separate fields:
- 'data' - A serialized event that conforms to schema specified by 'id'. Metadata field is optional for Analytics Pipeline events.
- 'additionalFields' - An optional structure that will be sent in addition to the 'data' of the event. This additional data will be attached in a different way for each collector: for events headed to Analytics Platform, the data will be sent as a single string field containing serialized JSON. (The schema of the event must contain a field named 'additionalFields'.) For events headed to New Relic, all of the fields will be sent mixed in with the 'data', with each field name prepended with 'additionalFields.'.
parameters.name: eventData

post.description:
**Description**
            A debug API to force-load the ACLSDK, even if configured off.
            Can only be used internally for testing.
post.summary: Force-load the ACLSDK

post.description:
**Requirements**
This should only be used by products launched via the Tencent Launcher.

This function is disabled unless the following configuration is passedto the SDK at startup:
* `publisher`: must be set to `tencent`
* `auth-via-tencent-launcher`: must be set to `true`

Requires ACLSDK.dll to be present. If absent, calling this functionwill return a `501` error code.


            **Description**

            Initializes the ACLSDK, retrieves the player's Tencent credentials
            from the Tencent Launcher, and uses them to auth with RSO via the
            partner-auth API.

            **Request Arguments**
            * `tencentGameId` - The Tencent-supplied game ID
            * `tencentGameKey` - The Tencent-supplied game key

            **Returns**
            A successful return indicates that the player has successfully authed
            with RSO.

            A failed return indicates an error, either with ACLSDK, or the resulting
            RSO auth.

parameters.description: The Tencent-supplied game ID and key
parameters.name: arguments

post.summary: Initialize RSO login using mSDK credentials from the Tencent Launcher

get.description:
**Requirements**
This should only be used by products launched via the Tencent Launcher.

This function is disabled unless the following configuration is passedto the SDK at startup:
* `publisher`: must be set to `tencent`
* `auth-via-tencent-launcher`: must be set to `true`

Requires ACLSDK.dll to be present. If absent, calling this functionwill return a `501` error code.


            **Description**
            Retrieves the Tencent Launcher LoginInfo (credentials) from the
            ACLSDK. If logged in, the response will contain the required tokens
            for RSO auth, or for auth with other Tencent services like Midas.

            This endpoint may be subscribed to, and a notification will be
            generated when:
            * `/login` is successfully called, containing the Tencent-specific
              credentials,
            * The Tencent Launcher performs a periodic refresh of the credentials.

            **Returns**
            If `/login` has not yet successfully been called, a `404` error
            code is returned.

            If the login information is available, a structure is returned
            containing the fields:
            * `openid`
            * `token`
            * `channel`
            * `ext`

            These fields should be treated as opaque.
get.summary: Retrieves the mSDK credentials from the Tencent Launcher

put.description:
One of the challenges of using the asynchronous voice-chat settings endpoint (e.g., PUT /voice-chat/vX/settings/{productName}) is that a successful response returned by the endpoint simply means that the updates were received by the RiotGamesApi and will eventually be applied. Game teams are required to subscribe to the corresponding GET endpoint to receive notifications for when the change actually goes through, making it tricky to create a good UI experience around the voice settings. 
The main advantage of this synchronous version of the voice-chat settings endpoint is that it ensures the voice-chat settings update will either happen successfully or will be reverted back to the original voice-chat settings. Hence, game teams will be able to update their UI once a success is returned or do nothing if a failure is returned.

parameters.description: Name of the product to update settings of
parameters.name: productName

parameters.description: New settings
parameters.name: settings

put.summary: Update current voice chat settings synchronously

get.description:
**Description**
Get the status of the voice-chat plugin to know whether or not to expect if the feature is usable. Game teams are encouraged to subscribe
to this endpoint so that the game can behave correctly depending on what the current state of the plugin is. For example, if the status of
the plugin is `permissionDenied`, game teams should not attempt to join voice sessions since the player does not have permissions to do so,
possibly due to behavioural restrictions or parental control settings.

** Returns **

A PluginStatus value representing the current status of the plugin.
* `PluginStatus` values:
    * `permissionDenied`: The player does not have permission to use voice chat. Attempting to join a voice session will always return an error and existing sessions will be left.
    * `awaitingAuth`: The player has not signed in, so the plugin does not have the information required to join a voice session.
    * `ready`: Voice chat is usable and voice sessions can be joined.
    * `unknown`: The status of the plugin is currently unknown. This is the default value while the plugin is initializing and its status has yet to be determined.
get.summary: Get the status of the voice-chat plugin to know whether or not to expect if the feature is usable.

get.description: Use this endpoint to determine if the user has granted access to the microphone for voice. Returns an enum that indicates if permission is denied/granted, or if permission needs to be obtained through the prompt-for-permission endpoint.
get.summary: Returns true if the user has permission to use the microphone.

put.description:
On Mac OS, starting from 10.14 (Mojave), we must ask the user for permission to access the microphone. Until they accept the prompt, or if they decline, the microphone will be unavailable, and voice will not be transmitted.
Before joining a voice channel, users of this plugin should call PUT on this endpoint while being subscribed for updates to /voice-chat/v2/devices/capture/permission. If 'permission' is updated to 'true', the listener must leave and re-join the voice channel to enable the microphone.
If the user has already granted or denied permission, this endpoint does nothing. The endpoint always returns immediately with success.
put.summary: Prompts the user for permission to use the microphone, if required.
